hints_raw:
Use integration by parts.
Let <math>u=\ln{x}, dv = \frac{dx}{x^2}</math>.
question: 1 (d)
sols_html:
Simple substitution does not work in this problem, so we will need to integrate by parts. Let \(\displaystyle u=\ln{x}\) and \(dv=\frac{dx}{x^2}=x^{-2}dx\). Then \(du=\frac{dx}{x}\) and \(v=-x^{-1}=-\frac{1}{x}\). Thus,

\(\int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\int \left ( -\frac{1}{x} \right ) \left ( \frac{dx}{x} \right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}+\int \left (\frac{dx}{x^2}\right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\frac{1}{x}.\)

Evaluating the definite integral then gives

\(\int_{1}^{e}\frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=\left ( -\frac{\ln{e}}{e}-\frac{1}{e} \right )- \left ( -\frac{\ln{1}}{1}-\frac{1}{1} \right )= \left(-\frac{2}{e} \right )- \left( 0-1 \right )=-\frac{2}{e}+1.\)

Therefore, the correct answer is (i).
sols_latex:
Simple substitution does not work in this problem, so we will need to
integrate by parts. Let $\displaystyle u=\ln{x}$ and
$dv=\frac{dx}{x^2}=x^{-2}dx$. Then $du=\frac{dx}{x}$ and
$v=-x^{-1}=-\frac{1}{x}$. Thus,

$\int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\int \left ( -\frac{1}{x} \right ) \left ( \frac{dx}{x} \right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}+\int \left (\frac{dx}{x^2}\right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\frac{1}{x}.$

Evaluating the definite integral then gives

$\int_{1}^{e}\frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=\left ( -\frac{\ln{e}}{e}-\frac{1}{e} \right )- \left ( -\frac{\ln{1}}{1}-\frac{1}{1}
\right )= \left(-\frac{2}{e} \right )- \left( 0-1 \right )=-\frac{2}{e}+1.$

Therefore, the correct answer is (i).
sols_raw:
Simple substitution does not work in this problem, so we will need to integrate by parts. Let <math>\displaystyle u=\ln{x}</math>  and <math>dv=\frac{dx}{x^2}=x^{-2}dx</math>. Then <math>du=\frac{dx}{x}</math>  and <math> v=-x^{-1}=-\frac{1}{x}</math>. Thus,
 
<math>
\int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\int \left ( -\frac{1}{x} \right ) \left ( \frac{dx}{x} \right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}+\int \left (\frac{dx}{x^2}\right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\frac{1}{x}.
</math>

Evaluating the definite integral then gives 

<math>
\int_{1}^{e}\frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=\left ( -\frac{\ln{e}}{e}-\frac{1}{e} \right )- \left ( -\frac{\ln{1}}{1}-\frac{1}{1}
\right )= \left(-\frac{2}{e} \right )- \left( 0-1 \right )=-\frac{2}{e}+1.
</math>

Therefore, the correct answer is (i).
statement_html:
Multiple Choice Question: Select ONE correct answer (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), or (v).

(d) The value of the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^e \frac{\ln(x)}{x^2}\,dx\end{aligned}\]

is

(i)   \(\displaystyle {} 1-\frac2{e}\)

(ii)   \(\displaystyle {} 1+\frac2{e}\)

(iii)   \(\displaystyle {} 1\)

(iv)   \(\displaystyle {} \frac1{e^2}-1\)

(v)   \(\displaystyle {} \frac{\ln(e)}{e^2}-\ln(1)\)
statement_raw:
Multiple Choice Question: Select '''ONE''' correct answer ''(i)'', ''(ii)'', ''(iii)'', ''(iv)'', or ''(v)''.

'''(d)''' The value of the integral
:<math>
\int_1^e \frac{\ln(x)}{x^2}\,dx
</math>
is

:''(i)'' &nbsp; <math>\displaystyle{} 1-\frac2{e} </math>

:''(ii)'' &nbsp; <math>\displaystyle{} 1+\frac2{e} </math> 

:''(iii)'' &nbsp; <math>\displaystyle{} 1 </math> 

:''(iv)'' &nbsp; <math>\displaystyle{} \frac1{e^2}-1 </math> 

:''(v)'' &nbsp; <math>\displaystyle{} \frac{\ln(e)}{e^2}-\ln(1) </math>
